text:
Heart arrhythmias currently
affect nearly 60 million people

in the United States, and
incur total health care costs
of around $20 billion annually.

Electrocardiograms, or EKGs,
record electrical activity

in the heart, and are the
mainstay of both diagnosis
and treatment.

However, patients often have
to wear EKGs for days to weeks

to wait to capture an
arrhythmia, which generates

large amounts of data that's
then manually interpreted
by a physician.

This interpretation process
is lengthy and prone
to error rates of up to 64%.

And patients continue to be at
risk of adverse cardiac events
while awaiting diagnosis.

Physicians are
burdened by this task,

inadequately reimbursed
by health insurers,

and unable to trust existing
digital solutions to EKG
interpretation.

We at CardioPhi aim
to solve this problem

by using AI and machine
learning to detect and predict

heart arrhythmias in
a matter of minutes.

Our team brings
significant experience

in machine learning, health
care operations, and health care
venture development.

Unlike other AI technologies,
CardioPhi software

can detect atrial fibrillation
as well as a clinician,

and explain the reasoning
behind decision-making,

which allows physicians and
patients to trust this tool

to expedite diagnosis
and treatment.

To date, we have already
published six research articles

and filed for two patents
related to these technologies.

To develop our proof of concept
and path to commercialization,

we're excited to participate
in the HBS New Venture

Competition, and innovate
upon a 120-year-old device.
